subject: Photography
title: The Bayer Filter Array
description: A fast breakdown of The Bayer Filter Array for builders.

hook.text: Almost every digital camera uses a pattern invented in 1976 by a Kodak scientist named Bryce Bayer.

buildup.text: The Bayer array places red, green, and blue filters over each pixel in a repeating pattern: RGGB.

discovery.text: There are twice as many green filters as red or blue. Why? Human eyes are most sensitive to green light.

twist.text: Each pixel only captures one color. The other two are mathematically guessed from neighboring pixels.

climax.text: This 'demosaicing' process works so well you'd never suspect two-thirds of your photo's color is invented.

punchline.text: Two-thirds of every pixel's color is a clever guess.

quiz.question: Why does the Bayer array have more green filters?
options: Human eyes are most sensitive to green light
